I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Mongolia,  during  the  country  programming  mission  held  in 
Ulaanbaatar in March 2018, requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a lending 
support to prepare the Forestry Sector Development Program (formerly the Community-Based 
Sustainable Forest Management and Policy Reform Project). The ensuing loan is included in 
ADB’s country operations business plan for Mongolia, 2020–2021 and the proposed transaction 
technical assistance (TA) is included in ADB’s nonlending pipeline for 2018.1 
 
2.  The forestry sector is underdeveloped in Mongolia and has limited economic contribution 
despite its potential for growth and livelihood opportunities, particularly in the rural areas. In line 
with the government’s focus to promote livelihood opportunities outside of the traditional livestock 
herding and mining, forestry has the potential to be a priority sector for diversified livelihoods and 
economic growth. With about 18.5 million hectares of forest land, accounting for approximately 
11.8% of the country’s land area, there are an abundance of forest resources. The forest sector 
is  conventionally  defined  as  commercial  activities  relating  to  the  extraction,  production, 
processing, sale and consumption of wood products and sometimes non-timber forest products. 
Mongolia has a small forestry manufacturing sector with potential to grow. In addition to the wood 
products, forests serve an important role in providing ecosystem goods and services that are vital 
to human health, wildlife habitat and diversity, watershed services, carbon storage, and scenic 
landscapes. 
 
3.  The project aims to increase income generating opportunities from forests by improving 
sector functions and services, applying sustainable forest management to improve forest health, 
protection, and resources, and support the growth of the forest industry and forest products. The 
project will: (i) support sector development through enabling policies, institutional reform and 
strengthening, and operationalizing a management information system; (ii) implement sustainable 
forest management at the local level by building capacity and systems to support forest user 
groups involvement in forest management and develop livelihood opportunities; and (iii) support 
the rehabilitation and modernization of the forest industry to increase production, resource use 
efficiency, improve product quality, enhance value chains, and increase inclusive and equitable 
benefit sharing along the value chain. 
 
 4.  The ensuing project is estimated to cost $40.4 million. ADB is requested to finance $40.0 
million largely for investment, policy and sector reform, and capacity building through a loan. The 
central and local governments will provide in-kind contribution equivalent to $0.4 million. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
5.  The executing agency, the Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MET), has limited 
experience  with  ADB  requirements  for  loan  preparation.  The  transaction  TA  will  help  the 
government prepare a project design that complies with the ADB requirements and international 
best practice.2

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $0.88 million, of which $0.8 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB.3 The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
8.  The  following  are  ineligible  items  under  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction:  (i) 
purchase of vehicles, (ii) salaries for civil servants, (iii) foreign travel, (iv) scholarships or long 
internships, (v) detailed engineering design, (vi) civil works and other related expenses, and (vii) 
those under ADB’s List of Ineligible Items (or Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities 
List.  
 
9.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, domestic 
transportation, data collection, logistic support in arranging workshops and field visits, and other 
in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project. 
 
3  Administered by the Asian Development Bank.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB will administer the TA. The MET will be the executing agency. The Department of 
Forest Policy and Coordination of MET will provide guidance during project preparation. The 
project implementation unit will be situated at MET to coordinate and oversee project preparation 
and implement the project. The TA will be implemented over 18 months, tentatively from January 
2020  to  June  2021.  Equipment  for  the  TA  consultants  will  be  procured  following  ADB’s 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated Staff Instructions 
and handed over to MET upon the TA completion. Disbursements under the TA will be in line with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
